captions.text:
The Clio RS versus Fiesta
ST debate has raged on
for some time now.

But there's now some added
confusion to the subject,

because Ford has just announced
its Mountune

Performance upgrade for the
ST. And on paper, it looks
damn impressive.

Until this point, the Clio's
argument was that-- despite
being more expensive--

it offered a 20 horsepower
advantage over the Ford, and a

snazzy paddle-operated
jewel clutch gearbox.

The trouble was the ST actually
had the same 177 foot
pounds of torque as the Clio.

And it would appear that the
internet still prefers manual
transmissions.

Well, for an extra 599 pounds
and a quick stop at your Ford

dealer, you could now enjoy a
Fiesta ST with-- wait for it--

215 horsepower and 236 foot
pounds of torque.

That's more than a Sierra
Cosworth, in a Fiesta.

And it's still cheaper
than the Clio.

You'd have to say, life
is looking even
trickier for the Renault.

We've already driven
these cars quite
extensively on road and track.

We know that the Clio, even with
the Cup chassis fitted,
is more subtle on the road.

But the Fiesta is firmer
and more aggressive.

What we don't know is which is
fastest in a straight line.
And this stuff matters.
So time to find out.
This is seconds out.

Well, it's round
one, isn't it?
This is Clio versus Fiesta.
It's very, very hot today.
And I mean very, very hot.

30 degrees for us in the UK
is a proper heat wave.

So what we're going to do
is we are going to have
a little drag race.
I'm in the Sport Clio.

Dan is in the ST with
the Mountune kit.

There's a suspicion that
that's a right giant
slayer, that is.
Go!
[CAR ENGINES]

Now, because I don't have
to do anything-- look.

No hands, and I'm still
beating a Fiesta.
But look what happens.

Once that thing starts
to go, it's above
65, 70 miles an hour.
It just disappears.
And it's cheaper.
Yes.
I know.
It's compelling.
It's compelling.
The Clio first.

Using its excellent launch
control, the driver really has

to do nothing but keep that
right pedal buried and let the
computer work its magic.
The results are pretty good.

On this slightly broken
surface, it
manages 60 in 6.8 seconds--

which is a little slower
than claimed--
and 100 in 16.8 seconds.

If you're old like me, you'll
still think that anything that

could run sub-20 to 100
is quite quick.

The Fiesta feels way
punchier, though.

Initial traction is so
good, you can just
drive it off the line.

But you have to feather the
throttle atop of first gear

before snatching second
as fast as the
synchros will allow.

And then the Fiesta
just flies.

It actually feels a good deal
quicker than the Clio above 50
miles an hour.

But the initial launch
isn't quite as good.

So the 0 to 60 is only 3/10
faster, at 6.5 seconds.
Again, slower than claimed.

But from 60 to 100, the
Fiesta rips 1.4
seconds from the Clio.
It's just miles faster.

I mean, a factory warranteed
supermini that does 0 to 100

in 15.4 seconds is pretty silly,
in a very good way.

But there's more to
it than that.

There is really more
to it than that.

And everyone is hating on this
Clio and lavishing praise on
that Fiesta.

And I just don't see
the distinction as
being as great as that.

There are things that that does,
that this does better.
I really think that.

I don't understand
why everyone's
out to get the Clio.

Let's have a further
think on that.

We've already driven these
two on road and track.

So I don't want to cover
the same ground twice.

They're quite different
in character actually.

But I don't buy into the
consensus that the
Ford kills the Clio.

I like how subtle the Renault
is on the road.

Afterwards, the ST is very firm,
and the steering seems
artificially heavy at times.

Strangely, this Fiesta was much
more mobile at the rear

axle than the last one we drove,
making it more fun.

But the Clio is equally
happy to oversteer
on a trailing throttle.

And as for the paddle shift,
in normal mode, I agree.
It's just a bit too slow.

But in race mode, you can
really settle back, and

pretend you're driving
a little Group N
tarmac rally car.

The more I drove it, the
more I enjoyed it.

I think its chassis is actually
the better of the two
for UK road driving.

But the Fiesta is the
bargain of the
moment at 17,594 pounds.

The cabin is a little bare next
to the 20-grand Clio.

But all the stuff that matters
in a hot hatch is good enough.
Especially the seats.

Renault has unrivaled heritage
in this category.

This new Clio is still
a very good car.

And if you want paddles,
you'll love it.

But the Fiesta is that rare
product, which somehow seems

to be just what people
want now.
It's fast.
It has a manual gearbox.
It's attractive.

And most importantly, it's
stunning value for money.
Ford has nailed it.

There is however a postscript
to this story.

Renault makes an even
faster Clio, too.

The only problem is, it doesn't
have number plates.
OK, peoples.

This is the new Clio Cup car,
for those that want to go
really fast in a hatchback.

Now, Silverstone Circuit is
rather tight and complicated.

This is the Stowe circuit
that we're on.
And it's a bit of a challenge.

Car needs to get some tire
temperature in it, but let's
talk around it.

Because there's something
about front-wheel
drive racing cars.
[CAR ENGINE]

220 horsepower, so effectively
the same engine as you get in
the street car.

But this time with a Sadev
six-speed gearbox, which is a
thing of quite some joy.

I think the main difference is
the last Clio racing car I

drove is this one doesn't have
a servo on the brakes.

So you really have to shove the
brakes when you get wicked
feel through.

It's a right little
tiny cup of car.
I just love these little cars.
They're brilliant.
[CAR ENGINE]

Of course, the secret to making
a front-wheel drive car

go quick on the circuit
is to it nervous.

Then have some oversteer,
but you can make it
turn so much quicker.
Dead impressive.
Brake pedal is just awesome.

And you've got [INAUDIBLE]
brake the car, so
aggressively.
Steering, well.
Very quick rack.
Very quick rack.

But the strange thing is how
different it is to the street

car, in that it's all about
the differential.

It's all about getting some
drive into that diff.
[CAR ENGINE]

And then just using it
now, winding it up.
The traction is phenomenal.

You'd swear the thing was
four-wheel drive.

This is a profoundly more
professional car than the Clio
road car I drove.

Really feels like a little
touring car.

Look at this lovely dashboard
ahead of me.
Cool steering wheel.

All the things that the
gentleman driver wants.
Those little trinkets.
Now, I like a bit of this.

If you want to really drive a
hatchback, you need to come
drive a Cup car.

title: Renault Clio RS 200 EDC v Ford Fiesta ST Mountune - /CHRIS HARRIS ON CARS

comments.text: Clio Cup??? Fiesta WRC!!!﻿

comments.text:
After watching again its clear that....
The Clio starts almost a second behind the Clio yet looks like it beats it 
off the line on other clips.

There is no more body roll in the clio than the fiesta if anything fiesta 
looks like it rolls more

Clio can change gear A LOT quicker.

Im starting to think more and more that the whole argument these journos 
are giving that the clio is worse than the fiesta is based purely on the 5 
doors and paddleshift gearbox. I strongly suspect the Clio is really the 
better car and its obvious the mk2 will destroy the fiesta.﻿

comments.author: juffurey

comments.text:
Who cares about gear change speed, I want a 3 pedals and a lever.

Clio is more expensive and leans more towards the luxury end of the hot 
hatch market (the Ford is quite spartan on toys but for me it's a plus 
point for this class of car).

I drive a Fiesta Zetec S at the moment and honestly it's the best thing 
I've ever owned, affordable, fun and relatively cheap to buy and run. 

Will be changing to the ST as soon as. 

I love Renaultsport offerings but the clio's flappy' box was an error on 
their part, I have only seen one on the road, yet I must have seen around 
20 if not more Fiesta STs.

comments.text: i don't see the appeal of either of them﻿

God... What a stupid arguement: "Hate it because it's french". The Mégane 
RS happened to be voted by Fifth and Top Gear as the best Hot Hatchback

the car even though it's alot smaller. Americans only know horsepower, they 
never learned to use efficienty and ergonomics in their cars, only Ford 
seems to be able to do a reasonable job at it.

appealing and aggressive looking - The Clio feels more grown up which might 
be good for non Hot Hatch versions but for HH not so. Good comparison.﻿

comments.text:
昨日ポストした、フィエスタSTのチューンドモデルとルーテシアRSの比較。

comments.author: Zoghlami Ahmed

comments.text:
Chris, just a little tip from an engineer and racer, please DOWNSHIFT when 
pulling from corners! If you're going for speed, you need to keep the 
engine at the thick end of the rev range (making more power). high-end 
power in 2nd > low-end torque in 3rd. I don't care if you're bouncing off 
the limiter.﻿
comments.author: TheArfdog

comments.text:
+TheArfdog Thank you for getting the torque/hp thing down right. A car 
always accelerates fastest in the lowest possible gear, no matter where the 
torque band max lies.
comments.author: Jeremy J.

comments.text:
+Eatdirt13 Tiff would certainly win since he has more race experience, 
LeMans, etc and he's just plain fast. Diesels are slow unless they rev out. 
A diesel that revs 3000 rpm must be making double the torque of a similar 
gasoline engine to just equal the horsepower. Only then is it comparable. 
But if it only makes 50% more torque, it will be slower.
comments.author: TheArfdog

comments.text:
+TheArfdog Torque is nothing without revs? What about diesels then? Most 
have hardly any power at the top end of the rev range and 'usually' peak HP 
is around 2,500 - 3,000 rpm. I know there are no diesels in the video but 
just saying!  Also, I'm pretty sure Chris Harris know what he's doing! :) 
Would love to see a race between Chris and Tiff Needell!
comments.author: Eatdirt13

comments.text:
+Matthew Butler And I meant he should downshift to be in a lower gear than 
he was in the video, which happened to be entering some corners, misspoke 
on that.
comments.author: TheArfdog

comments.text:
+Matthew Butler Incorrect. For max acceleration (and ease of modulation if 
it exceeds traction ability), the engine should be at its horsepower peak, 
which is not at the low end of the rev range, even in an engine with good 
torque. Torque is nothing without revs (hence the equation for power). Also 
gear change time in the middle of a straight is unimportant, since you're 
still going 100 mph (or whatever) mid-shift. Lap data will show you that.
comments.author: TheArfdog

comments.text:
Downshift when pulling from corners? You should already be in the right 
gear exiting the corner! Anyway coming out of a corner (especially onto a 
straight) in a car with good torque is better in a slightly higher gear 
anyway, you'll have one less gear-change to make on the straight saving you 
time, and time saved on a straight constantly increases.
comments.author: Matthew Butler

comments.text:
pt 3 Some of the offramps etc, all Auckland NZ. Westbound on Esmonde Rd, 
descending left hander to get on to SH1 Northbound. Northbound on SH1, get 
off at Albany Expressway / Greville Rd, right hander on the roundabout and 
switch to the left that rises steeply to get back on SH1. Huia Rd and on to 
gravel on Whatipu Rd.
comments.author: getahanddown

comments.text:
pt 2 fix the right rear control arm length. Back on the road and trip 
around town hitting my favourite challenging tight on/off ramps and linking 
multiple roundabouts. No straight line stuff, yawn! It's the standard 
4S-FE, no point in drag races! Not fast like a good car through corners 
either but great fun getting used to how it behaves and challenging myself 
to keep it balanced and tidy (thats what you mean by unsafe ay?!) Afternoon 
I took it out on gravel to have lunch at the beach. cont
comments.author: getahanddown

comments.text:
BurqaKing! thats fricken awesome! Totally agree the track if the place to 
explore the limits. Had errands to do all day. Took the wagon out and slow 
to warm up / fluctuating temp. Also wouldn't stay composed when pushing on 
a tight 450 degree onramp that is well cambered but drops maybe 8m. To the 
shed to do the thermostat (stuck halfway open) and flush + new coolant. 
Check tyre pressures (had done that when I picked it up but checked for 
changes) still all the same so check alignment, ...cont
comments.author: getahanddown

comments.text:
again...who said i had better toys? yeh i do have fun - on the track -

better story and better toys. I wrung the crap out of a $400NZD Toyota
